data.title: Cannes 2013: Chileâ€™s onetime cult king still the wizard of weird
authors: Dennis Lim, Special to the Los Angeles Times
data.meta_description: Director Alejandro Jodorowsky says although his first film since 1990, 'The Dance of Reality,' may unnerve even his fans, at 84 he still has more movies to make.
data.text:
CANNES, France â€” The Chilean director Alejandro Jodorowsky has made only seven features in his nearly half-century career, but his legendary midnight movie â€œEl Topo,â€ a wigged-out peyote western that played to New York audiences for months in 1970, sealed his place in the annals of cult cinema.

Jodorowsky last made a comeback in 1989 with the Oedipal melodrama â€œSanta Sangre,â€ about a serial killer operating under the spell of his armless mother. When that project was announced at the Cannes Film Festival, a journalist wondered if a decade-long break from filmmaking had left Jodorowsky rusty. He responded: â€œA rusty knife is twice as deadly.â€

CHEAT SHEET: Cannes Film Festival 2013

Deadlier than ever, presumably, after an even longer absence, Jodorowsky, 84, has returned to directing with â€œThe Dance of Reality,â€ his first movie since 1990â€™s â€œThe Rainbow Thiefâ€ (a work-for-hire with Peter Oâ€™Toole and Omar Sharif that he has since disowned). Billed as a work of â€œimaginary autobiography,â€ â€œThe Dance of Realityâ€ is among the most eagerly anticipated titles in this yearâ€™s Directorâ€™s Fortnight section at Cannes, which is also screening â€œJodorowskyâ€™s Dune,â€ a documentary by Frank Pavich about Jodorowksyâ€™s fabled, doomed attempt in the mid-1970s to turn Frank Herbertâ€™s classic science-fiction novel into a big-screen space opera.

â€œEvery one of my pictures is different â€” I die and Iâ€™m reborn with each one,â€ Jodorowsky said last week by Skype from Nice, where he was on vacation, preparing for the Cannes maelstrom. Even over a spotty connection, the bearded Jodorowsky, with his shock of white hair and gleaming row of improbably perfect teeth, registered as larger than life. An expansive if rambling conversationalist, he apologized several times for his faltering English and his penchant for digressive rants. After one vigorous diatribe â€” on the evils of money â€” he said, with a smile: â€œYou know, you are speaking with a crazy person.â€

On the subject of his new film, which will have its first screening May 18 (along with Pavichâ€™s documentary), Jodorowsky declined to get into specifics. â€œI am like a mother with a son in my belly,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t want to think about it before the baby is born.â€

Jodorowsky described â€œThe Dance of Reality,â€ which he shot in his hometown of Tocopilla in the Chilean desert, as â€œpsychological time travel,â€ an attempt to give poetic yet concrete form to the first chapters of his colorful life.

Born to Russian Jewish Ã©migrÃ©s in 1929, Jodorowsky studied theater and worked as a circus clown and puppeteer in Santiago. In postwar Paris he performed mime with Marcel Marceau and fell in with the surrealists. He then moved to Mexico, where he mounted dozens of plays inspired by Antonin Artaudâ€™s theater of cruelty. Back in Paris, where he has lived since the 1980s, he cultivated multiple sidelines: writing comic books, studying the tarot and developing a therapeutic method known as psychomagic, rooted in both psychoanalysis and shamanism.

FULL COVERAGE: Film festivals

Psychomagic is the guiding philosophy of â€œThe Dance of Reality,â€ a kind of home movie writ large. Jodorowskyâ€™s wife, Pascale Montandon, was the costume designer, and three of his sons appear in it, including Brontis (who in â€œEl Topoâ€ portrayed the son of the title character, a gunslinger known as â€œthe moleâ€ and played by Alejandro Jodorowsky). In the new film, Brontis, now 50, plays Jodorowskyâ€™s Stalin-lookalike father, whom the director described as â€œa very terrible father, a very hard man, but he had his reasons.â€

â€œBefore we started, I said to the crew, â€˜I am trying to heal my soul,â€™â€ Jodorowsky said. â€œBut itâ€™s not an egocentric, narcissistic picture. Poetry doesnâ€™t speak about history. It speaks about interior life, universal problems.â€

â€œThe Dance of Realityâ€ came about when Jodorowsky reconnected with the producer Michel Seydoux through Pavichâ€™s film on â€œDune.â€ They had not spoken in years, each nursing his wounds from the abortive project, which was to have starred Orson Welles and Mick Jagger and featured a Pink Floyd score. David Lynch eventually brought Herbertâ€™s book to the screen in 1984, but Jodorowskyâ€™s unmade version has exerted its own influence â€” not least thanks to his would-be collaborators, who included artist H.R. Giger, cartoonist Jean â€œMoebiusâ€ Giraud and screenwriter Dan Oâ€™Bannon, all of whom worked on Ridley Scottâ€™s â€œAlien.â€

Nicolas Winding Refn, a fan of Jodorowskyâ€™s who dedicated â€œDriveâ€ to him (and is back in Cannes this year with â€œOnly God Forgivesâ€), appears in the documentary to make the provocative suggestion that had Jodorowskyâ€™s â€œDuneâ€ been made â€” and been a hit instead of â€œStar Warsâ€ â€” it could have changed the course of mainstream cinema.

Unrealized projects loom over Jodorowskyâ€™s career, among them an â€œEl Topoâ€ sequel and a gangster film, â€œKing Shot,â€ that was to have starred Nick Nolte and Marilyn Manson. The money men inevitably pulled out for the same reasons, Jodorowsky said: â€œTheyâ€™re afraid, they think itâ€™s too surrealist, too weird.â€

Jodorowsky, by his admission, is not his own best salesman. For â€œThe Dance of Reality,â€ he said, â€œI told the producer, â€˜I want to make a picture to lose money.â€™ I am tired of all that money. Movies are an art, not a business.â€

Jodorowsky once argued that â€œheadâ€ movies should not merely simulate psychedelic visions â€” they should supplant the need for drugs. These days his musings on the power of cinema have a more spiritual bent. â€œI ask to movies everything I can ask to a sacred book: Bible, Koran, Torah,â€ he said.

â€œMovies were the hope of human culture. The Surrealists thought it was the real new art of the century, but now itâ€™s the worst. The first illness is the producer, and the second illness is stars. They kill the art, the big, big egos who believe in nothing.â€ Heâ€™s also no fan of digital technology, which creates â€œscientific images, very clear, with color like a painting,â€ he said. â€œYou see a tiger in a film and you have no emotion because you know it is not real. You admire the technique but you donâ€™t believe there is any danger.â€

In the Jodorowsky universe, to make art is to risk something, whether it be safety, sanity or ridicule. He shot â€œSanta Sangreâ€ in actual slums and red-light districts, working with real-life criminals. On the new film, the production had to contend with extreme pollution from the local copper mines. â€œEverything is poison there,â€ he said. â€œAfter two months we were all ill.â€

A onetime emblem of the counterculture, Jodorowsky is now, in his way, an elder statesman. â€œFando y Lisâ€ (1967), his violent first film, prompted a riot at its Acapulco premiere, but â€œEl Topoâ€ and the even more outrageous â€œHoly Mountainâ€ (1973), both newly restored, have found appreciative younger audiences; the Museum of Modern Art in New York presented a retrospective of his work two years ago.

To hear him tell it, though, Jodorowskyâ€™s troublemaking days may not be behind him. â€œWait until you see my new picture â€” maybe that will destroy everything,â€ he said with a laugh. â€œI believe 100% in what I did, but this film is not similar to the past. Itâ€™s a step into nothingness.â€

An autobiographical work by an octogenarian, â€œThe Dance of Realityâ€ begs to be read as a culminating work, but Jodorowksy refuses to think of it as a swan song. â€œPeople are prejudiced about my age,â€ he said. â€œThey think you become an idiot. But to have more years is to become more wise. They say I am old, but to me 84 is young. I think I can make four or five more pictures. I am not in a hurry.â€
